message: I have a Rails application I'm working on that needs to handle photo uploads for something - basically, there's a Person, and then there are PersonPhotos (Person has_many :person_photos). How can I handle photo uploads when you're creating a new person, as well as when you're editing a person? I was thinking of using https://github.com/nathancolgate/s3-swf-upload-plugin to avoid having to deal with the uploads on my end, but can't figure out how to use that on a 'new Person' page without having a bunch of stale uploads if someone uploads a bunch of photos for a person, but doesn't save it.

I'm not sure if I really understand your question.  I've used carrierwave for file uploads to both the application filesystem and to s3.  It's worked pretty well for me but certainly won't be as sexy as a swf based upload.

I'll try to rephrase: The s3 upload plugin is awesome for sending my uploads straight to S3 - but how do I do uploads when the parent model is unsaved? If you're on the "Create a new Person" page and haven't set one up and you upload a bunch of photos but then *don't* create the new Person...how can I handle that case? Or do I just end up with a bunch of stale files?
Carrierwave looks pretty cool, I'll add that one to my list to check out
A few railscasts that might help:
@benzittlau  @girasquid I second paperclip. I found it very easy to get working, and it did a nice job.
Yup, paperclip is great! Used it on many projects.
I've used Paperclip and CarrierWave. I prefer CarrierWave.
+1 for carrierwave. As for the other problem, allow photos to be on their own, and periodically clean out ones that aren't attached to anything.
@chrisyour why CarrierWave over Paperclip? You're the only response that mentions using both, so I'm curious about why you chose one over the other.
@darkhelmetlive thanks - that was the real question I was asking, I definitely could have worded it better.

@girasquid First off, with CarrierWave, you only need to add one column to your model - rather than four columns with Paperclip. I also like that CarrierWave puts the upload settings into a separate Uploader class rather than in each model.rb file.
